Speaker: fade in
Dialogue: The screen is a microcosm of leaf, crystal drops of precipitation, a stone, emerald green moss. It's a landscape in miniature. We HEAR the forest. Some distant birds. Their sound seems to reverberate as if in a cavern. A piece of sunlight refracts within the drops of water, paints a patch of moss yellow. The whisper of wind is joined by another sound that mixes with it. A distant rustling. It gets closer and louder. It's shallow breathing. It gets ominous. We're interlopers on the floor of the forest and something is coming.  SUDDENLY: A MOCCASINED FOOT

Speaker: tan
Dialogue: is a huge elk that leaps at the sound.

Speaker: chingachgook
Dialogue: Halloo! John Cameron!

Speaker: cameron
Dialogue: Alexandria! Set three more places.  How is Chingachgook, then?

Speaker: chingachgook
Dialogue: The Master of Life is good. Another year pass ... How is it with you, John?

Speaker: cameron
Dialogue: Gettin' along. Yes, it is.  Nathaniel.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Hello John. Cleared another quarter, I see.

Speaker: cameron
Dialogue: Yes, I did.

Speaker: alexandria
Dialogue: If Uncas is with you, that means he has not found a woman and started a family yet.

Speaker: chingachgook
Dialogue: Your eyes are too sharp, Alexandria Cameron. They see into my heart.

Speaker: uncas
Dialogue: Your farm good to you this year, John?

Speaker: cameron
Dialogue: It was a good year for corn.

Speaker: uncas
Dialogue: Mohawk field we saw was 5 mile long on the river. Chief Joseph Brandt's field.

Speaker: cameron
Dialogue: You take much fur?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: That we did. John. But the horicane  is near trapped out.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Tradin' your skins in Castleton?

Speaker: uncas
Dialogue: No, Schylerville. With the Dutch for silver. French & English want to buy with wampum & brandy.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: So what is it, Jack? What brings you up here?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: A French & Indian army out of Fort Carillon's heading south to war against the English. I'm here to raise this county's militia to aid the British defense.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Folks here goin' to join in that fight?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: We'll see in the morning ...

Speaker: chingachgook
Dialogue: Fathers of England & France, both, take more land, furs, than they need. They're cold & full of greed ...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Few'd deny that? Where you headin'?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Trap over the fall and winter among the Delawares in Can-tuck-ee.

Speaker: uncas
Dialogue: So I can find a woman and make Mohican children so our father will leave my brother & me in peace.

Speaker: james
Dialogue: A son like me?

Speaker: uncas
Dialogue: No. You are too strong. Turn me old too fast!

Speaker: alexandria
Dialogue: That's what he's doin' to his mama ...

Speaker: cameron
Dialogue: Dear Father, thank you for rewardin' the fruits of our labor with plenty. Amen.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: My father says he was driven out of France by the black robe priests and he would fight them now but he lost his arm and so I will go in his place.

Speaker: ongewasgone
Dialogue: John Cameron, thank you for your hospitality ... Twin River Mohawk got no quarrel with Les Francais. Trade furs with Les Francais. Now Les Francais bring Huron onto Mohawk hunting grounds ...

Speaker: ongewasgone
Dialogue: Now Mohawk will fight Huron and Les Francais. My brothers have asked me to lead them in this war so I speak for the Twin River Council.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: His Majesty King George II is very grateful for your support.

Speaker: ian
Dialogue: How far up the valley?

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: To Fort William Henry.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: It should be enough to remind you France is the enemy.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Your enemy ...

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: What did you say?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: I said ... France is your enemy. Not ours.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Really? Do you want them to overrun all New York colony?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: First place, you started it with the French over fur-trapping claims to the head waters of the Ohio.  Now you're sayin' these people have a fight on their hands ...

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Will you men help us stop the French?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: ... and while they are cooped up in your fort, what if the French send war parties to raid their homes?

Speaker: ian
Dialogue: What then, Lieutenant?

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: For your own homes, for king, for country, that's why you men ought to join this fight!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: You do what you want with your own scalp. Do not be tellin' us what to do with ours.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: You, sir! You call yourself a loyal subject?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: ... No ... Do not call myself much of a subject at all.

Speaker: ad libs
Dialogue: Yes. Yeah. No ...

Speaker: cameron
Dialogue: I am stayin' on my farm. And any man who goes, his family is welcome to fort-up with us 'til he comes back.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Boys. My sense of it is enough of us will join-up to fill the county's levy. But only if General Webb accepts a few terms I got in mind ...

Speaker: ian
Dialogue: You boys marchin' with us? What do you say?

Speaker: uncas
Dialogue: We had our say, Ian.

Speaker: sergeant major
Dialogue: Prime! Load!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: ... if they are not allowed leave to defend their families if the French or Hurons attack the settlements, no colonial militia is goin' to Fort William Henry.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: You, there. Help my man outside with the baggage.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: They will report or be pressed into service!

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: They will be found! Arrested ...

Speaker: webb
Dialogue: I cannot imagine his Majesty, in his benevolence, would ever object to his American subjects defending their hearth & home, their women & children, if threatened by the "scourge" of attack from savages, aroused to such excess by our enemy, the ever-perfidious French.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Does that mean they will be granted leave to defend their homes if the settlements are attacked?

Speaker: webb
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You got yourself a colonial militia, General.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Major Duncan Heyward reporting, Sir!

Speaker: webb
Dialogue: Duncan. How was your journey?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: I didn't experience anything so surprising from Bristol to Albany as what I witnessed here today.

Speaker: webb
Dialogue: And what is that?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: The Crown "negotiating" the terms of service?

Speaker: webb
Dialogue: I know.  But that's the way of it here.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: I thought British policy is 'Make the World ... England', sir.

Speaker: webb
Dialogue: You will take command of the 62nd Regiment of Foot. At Fort William Henry under Colonel Munro. I will march the 33rd to Fort Edward.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Sir! ... Might I enquire if General Webb has heard from Colonel Munro's daughters? I was to rendezvous with them in Albany and escort them to the fort.

Speaker: webb
Dialogue: Yes. You may.  The "Scotsman" has sent one of his Indian allies to guide you.

Speaker: webb
Dialogue: The Scotsman's daughters are at the Poltroon's house. A company of the 33rd will accompany you and Magua will show you the way.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: By your leave, sir.

Speaker: webb
Dialogue: Explain to the Major we care little about toying with colonial militia because we have little to fear from the French. They have not the nature for war. Their Latinate voluptuousness combines with their Gallic laziness and the result is: they would rather make love with their faces than fight.

Speaker: webb
Dialogue: Dismissed.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Dawn. At the encampment. Six a.m. sharp. See to it you're there.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Heyward! Duncan Heyward.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: My God it's good to see you.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: I'm embarrassed to be so indecisive ... after so long apart and after you've traveled so far ...

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: And by sea!

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: You still have an aversion to the water?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Aversion? No. ... "Hatred" ... "Loathing" ...

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: But it was worth it all to end in a garden by your side.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Dear Duncan, my affection is as towards a closest friend. Alice and I depend on you and respect you immensely ... I wish they did, but my feelings don't go beyond that. Do you see?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Isn't respect and friendship, a reasonable basis for a man and woman to be joined? And all else may grow in time ...?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Some say that's the way of it.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: "Some"?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Cousin Eugenie, my father, but ...

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Cora, in my heart, I know once we're joined, we'll be the happiest couple in England. Let those whom you trust, your father, help settle what's best for you. In view of your indecision, why not rely on their advice and judgment as well as mine?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Will you consider that?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Yes. Yes, I will.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Duncan!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: My God, you've grown up.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: We leave in the morning?!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Yes, miss.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: I won't sleep tonight. What an adventure! I absolutely cannot wait to return to Portman Square, having laid eyes upon the full-blooded, red men in the wild!

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: My God, Alice.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: It can be dangerous ...

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Nonsense. Papa wouldn't have sent for us if it were dangerous.

Speaker: ambrose
Dialogue: Atten-shun!

Speaker: ambrose
Dialogue: Shoulder arms!

Speaker: ambrose
Dialogue: Form two companies of nine ... MARCH!!

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Alice, did you see that ...?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Alice?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Are you alright?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Can we rest soon?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Absolutely.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: You there, Scout!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: We must ... stop ... soon. Women are ... tired. You ... understand?

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: I understand. This is not good place to stop. Two leagues from here. No water 'til then. That where we stop. Better place.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: No. Stop in the glade just ahead! When the ladies are rested, we will proceed. Do you understand?

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: "Magua understand paleface is a dog to his women. When his women want to eat, he lay aside his tomahawk to feed their laziness."

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Excuse me. What did you say?

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Magua say: "Yes. Good idea."

Speaker: ambrose
Dialogue: Form company! Left face! March!

Speaker: ambrose
Dialogue: Company make ready!

Speaker: ambrose
Dialogue: Present!!

Speaker: ambrose
Dialogue: Fire!!

Speaker: ambrose
Dialogue: Load! Prime!

Speaker: ambrose
Dialogue: Present! Present!

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: No, Duncan!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: ... case your aim is any better'n your judgment.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Stop it!

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: We need them to get out of here!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: ... why the bloody hell he do that to the horses?!

Speaker: uncas
Dialogue: ... too easy to track ... they can be heard for miles ... find yourself a musket ...

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Your wounded should try walkin' back to Albany. They'll never make a passage north.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: We were headed ...

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: ... Fort William Henry.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: ... take you as far as the fort.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: If we are goin' to take you, we need to move. Fast ... And the fort is well off our course. So if you all rather wait for the next Huron war party to come by, we'll be on our way.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: How far is it, scout?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Day and a half  Where did you get ... the guide?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Colonel Munro sent him. He was one of our Mohawk allies.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: He is Huron and nothing else.  Why would he want to murder the girl?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: What?!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Dark haired ...

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Miss Cora Munro. He never set eyes on her before today.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: No blood vengeance? No re-proach or insult?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Of course not!  And how is it you were nearby?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Came across the war party, tracked 'em.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Then you're assigned to Fort William Henry?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Fort Edward, then?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: No. Headin' west. To Can-tuck-ee.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: I thought all our colonial scouts were in the militia?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: I ain't your "scout". And I am in no damn militia.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Then you are one of those who would allow England to fight alone while she protects you from France?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: England does not protect me and does not war against France on our account. She uses us to war against France on her own account ... of greed for land and furs.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Clear it up any?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: I owe you gratitude or I'd call you out!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Do not let gratitude get in the way ...

Speaker: chingachgook
Dialogue: Yengeese no good in woods. Make more noise, I kill him.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Anything to be done?

Speaker: uncas
Dialogue: All dead ...

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Who were these people?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Ottawa!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Excuse me ...

Speaker: chingachgook
Dialogue: Ottawa.

Speaker: uncas
Dialogue: Mirrors ... tools ... clothes ... all inside.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Movin' fast, not able to carry much ... this was a war party?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Let us look after them ...

Speaker: chingachgook
Dialogue: Leave them.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Though they are strangers, they are at least entitled to a Christian burial!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Let us go, miss.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: I will not. I have seen the face of war before, Mr. Poe, but never war made on women and children. And almost as cruel is your indifference.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: They are not strangers .... And they stay as they lay ...!

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Why didn't you bury those people?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Anyone lookin' to pick up our trail, would see it as a sign of our passing ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: You knew them.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: You were acting for our benefit. And I apologize. I misunderstood you.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Well that is to be expected. My father ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Your "father"?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Chingachgook. He warned me about people like you.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: He did?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Yes. He said ... "do not try to make them understand you."

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: What?!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Yes. And "do not try to understand them. That is because they are a breed apart and they make no sense ..."

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Why did they turn back?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: "We're a breed apart and we make no sense" ...?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: In your particular case, miss, I would make some allowance ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Thank you so much.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: You called Chingachgook your "father"? Where is your real family?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: They buried my ma & pa and my sisters. And Chingachgook - who found me with two French trappers - raised me up as his own.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: I'm sorry.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: I do not remember them. I was one or two.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: How did you learn English?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: My father sent Uncas & I to Reverend Wheelock's school when I was ten. So we would know both worlds ... though we were told only bother learning readin' & arithmetic from yous.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: And what were the consequentialities of European culture you didn't bother with?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: The Bible. Monarchy. Many wrong ideas about the government of men. My father's people already know each man is his own nation. And only he can have dominion over himself. Not kings. No man is better than any other man.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: In London those radical ideas could land you in Newgate prison.  Why were those people living in this defenseless place ...?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: 'Cos frontier land's the only land affordable to poor people. So after seven years indentured service in Virginia, they headed out here where they are beholden to none and not livin' by another's leave ... Their name was Cameron. John & Alexandria.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: So there is the Camerons' monument ... my folks', too, I guess.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: You are right, Mr. Poe. We do not understand what is happening here. And it is not as I imagined it would be, thinking of it in Boston and London ...

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Sorry to disappoint you ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: ... than any imagining could possibly have been ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Much further?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Top of this ridge. Fort and Lake George are downhill of it.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Will we be able to bathe?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Thunder ... Papa will arrange something.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: The men of the regiment will fetch water from the lake, build fires and provide every comfort you desire, Alice ...

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Duncan, you are absolutely gallant. If Cora doesn't marry you, I shall.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Alice!

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: I can't wait to see Papa ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: And you, Duncan? What are you looking forward to?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Posting to a different continent.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: I think it's very important and exciting.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Lightning?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: I'm Major Duncan Heyward!

Speaker: beams
Dialogue: Captain Jeffrey Beams. We didn't think you'd make it through!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Where's Colonel Munro? His daughters are here, too.

Speaker: ad libs
Dialogue: Uncas! Nathaniel ...

Speaker: ian
Dialogue: Thought you and Nathaniel weren't joinin'-up.

Speaker: uncas
Dialogue: Didn't!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Dropped in to see how you boys is doin'.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Papa, Papa!!

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Why are you here?!

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Why did you allow them to come? ... And where the bloody hell are my reinforcements!!

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Told you to stay away from this hell hole! Why did you disobey me?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: When? How?

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: My letter ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: There was none!

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: There was no letter.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: I sent three men to Webb!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: One called Magua arrived.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: He delivered no such message.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Does Webb not even know we are besieged?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Sir. Webb has no idea. And he certainly does not know to send reinforcements!

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: What happened to you?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: ... eighteen killed. It's these men who saved us. They guided us here ...

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Thank you. How can I reward you?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Help ourselves to a few horns from your powder stores.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: What else?

Speaker: uncas
Dialogue: Some food.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: I'm indebted to you. And get your side sewn up, young man.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Mr. Phelps!

Speaker: phelps
Dialogue: Miss Cora! How are you?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: And we could use some rum, clothes, and a place to wash ...

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: What a place for them ...

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Might I enquire after the situation, sir, given that I've seen of the French engineering from the ridge above?

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Logistics are his guns are bigger than mine and he has more of them. They keep our heads down while his sappers make thirty yards of trench a day. His thirteen inch mortars have a two hundred yard range, so when they're close enough, they'll move them in, lob explosive rounds over our walls and pound us to dust.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: They look to be three hundred yards out. You have three days.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Bloody murderers.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: A man, here, can make a run straight through to Webb.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: ... not enough time to get to Albany and back with reinforcements ...

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Webb's not in Albany. He marched the 33rd to Fort Edward two days ago.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Webb's at Edward?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Only twelve miles away! He could be here day after tomorrow.  Find your man, sir! Captain Beams will give you the message.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: John Cameron's cabin. We come upon it last night. Burned out. Everyone murdered. And it was Ottawa. They're allied to the French.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Yes, Mr. Poe? So?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: It was a war party. It means they're on the attack up and down the frontier.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Many men here, their homes are in the path.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: That's all, sir.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Things were done. Nobody was spared ...

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Terrible feature of war in the Americas.  Best to keep your sight fixed on our duty. Our duty is to defeat France. That hangs on a courier to Webb.

Speaker: seneca chief
Dialogue: ... and the Black Robes of Michilimackinac left us no time to put our cabins in order before telling us our French father had need of our aid. We rolled our blankets and were the first to be here. Yet we are not the first and closest to my father's campfire.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: For my children and the children of the true faith, my friendship and esteem is boundless ... I will give you three oxen for a feast and tomorrow I, myself, will sing the war song with you in the great council house.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Le Renard Subtil, how are things with your English friends?

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Louis Antoine, join us.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Hear what le Subtil has to tell us ...

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: English war chief, Webb goes to Fort Edward with 33rd Regiment. He does not know my father's army attacks Fort William Henry.

Speaker: bougainville
Dialogue: But by now Munro knows his couriers didn't get through. He'll send another.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: The Grey Hair will try.

Speaker: bougainville
Dialogue: Four or five, including two women entered the fort ...

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: The Grey Hair's children were under Magua's knife but escaped. They'll be under it again.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Why do hate the Grey Hair, Magua?

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: When the Grey Hair is dead, Magua will eat his heart. Before he dies Magua will put his children under the knife so the Grey Hair will see his seed is wiped out forever.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: My sappeurs are advancing the trenches through the night, now. You may have your opportunity soon.

Speaker: phelps
Dialogue: First assisted me in Austria when she was fourteen. I would say she does ...

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: She does not shy away from much ...

Speaker: phelps
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Nothin'.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Mr Poe?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Miss.  May I?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: You 'bout done holdin' hands with Miss Munro?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: What are you looking at, Mr. Poe?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Why, I am looking at you, Miss.

Speaker: uncas
Dialogue: You told him about the raid?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: But he is gonna have to.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Get together by the West Battery James & Ian, Sharitarish & William.

Speaker: uncas
Dialogue: Tight weave.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Another forty yards?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Sergeant! Form three ranks!

Speaker: sergeant major
Dialogue: Sir!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Fire!!!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Advance, Sergeant Major!

Speaker: sergeant major
Dialogue: Sir!!!  Third rank! Twelve paces! Forward march!

Speaker: sergeant major
Dialogue: Shoulder arms!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Fire!!!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Sergeant Major!

Speaker: sergeant major
Dialogue: Sir!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Thank you, Sergeant Major. Thank the men.

Speaker: sergeant major
Dialogue: Atten-hut!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Cora ... I wanted to talk to you, but I'll come back another time ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Alice ...

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Talk to Duncan, Cora ... I must manage ... I cannot be an invalid schoolgirl.  I'll see if Mr. Phelps needs anything ...

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Her nerves are shattered. She's trying to be brave.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Cora, I adore you and, when we come together, we will be the happiest couple in England ... I am certain of that. More than ever before.  I believe you must trust the judgment of others who hold your welfare so close to their hearts ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Duncan ...  Duncan, I promised you an answer. You have complimented me with your persistence and patience ... But the decision I've come to is I'd rather make the gravest of mistakes than surrender my own judgment.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: And it's been unfair to you, while I search myself for feelings, which, if they were there and as strong as they ought to be, would've made themselves known long ago ...  Take my admiration and friendship, Duncan. And please take this as my final answer. It must be no.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: I see ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: I am sorry, Duncan ...

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: I must receive proof more conclusive than Mr. Poe's opinion before I weaken our defenses by allowing militia to withdraw.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Chingachgook's of the same opinion. Taken together, that's gospel. Your fort will     stand or fall depending on Webb and reinforcements, not these colonials' presence.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: I judge military matters, Captain Winthrop, not you.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: That judgment is not more important than their right under agreement with Webb to defend their farms & families ... Major Heyward was at John Cameron's. He saw what it was.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: What did you see, Major?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: I saw nothing that would lead me to the conclusion it was other than a raid by savages bent on thievery.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: You're a liar!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: And the blood is on your hands!

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Montcalm is a soldier and a gentleman. Not a butcher.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Easy for you to suppose. While it is their women and children, not yours, alone in their farms!

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: You forget yourself!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: We are not forgettin' Webb's promise!

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: British promises are honored. And the militia will not be released. Because I need more definite proof than this man's word!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Nathaniel's word been good on the frontier a long time before you got here!

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: This interview's over! The militia stays!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Does the rule of English law no longer govern? Has it been replaced by absolutism?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: And if English law cannot be trusted, maybe these people would do better makin' a peace with the French!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: That is sedition! Treason!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: That is the truth!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: I ought to have you whipped from this fort!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Major!  Some day I think you and I are gonna have a serious disagreement.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: My decision is final. Get out.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: ... got no kin in the settlements. If I did, I'd be long gone.

Speaker: ian
Dialogue: You didn't think it right to be here in the first place.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: By my light that's how I saw it then and I see it that way now ...

Speaker: ian
Dialogue: But we are under English military authority.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I believe if they set aside their law as and when they wish, their law no longer has rightful authority over us. All they have over us is tyranny, then. And I'll stay here no longer. No force on earth will keep me here ... Anyone caught leavin' the fort could be shot. So each man make your own decision ... Those who are goin', be back here in an hour.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Out the northern sally-port. Strike for the east side of the swamp until you clear the French picket line. Head north over the ridge, then come about southeast and fork left in Little Meadow and you're free of the outpost and skirmishers ...

Speaker: a colonial
Dialogue: Should've skinned outta this long ago.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: I'll cover them from the top of the casement.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You're not coming with us?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Got a reason to stay.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: That reason wear a blue dress and work in the surgery?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Good luck, Jack.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: As you were!!

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Take him!

Speaker: chingachgook
Dialogue: Why do they make my son prisoner?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: I helped Winthrop and the others leave ... This fight is not yours, father. I love you and my brother. And you should leave this place now and go to Can-tuck-ee ...

Speaker: chingachgook
Dialogue: What will they do with my white son?

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Get back from him!

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: He saved us! We are alive only because of him ...

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: The man encouraged the colonials to desert in this very room, in my presence. He is guilty of sedition and must be tried and hanged like any other criminal, regardless of what he did for my children.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: He knew the consequences. And he stayed. Are those the actions of a criminal? ... Duncan, do something.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: He knew the penalty for breaking regulations. He ought to pay without sending you to beg.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: You know he wouldn't send me ...! You misrepresented what you saw and caused this.  I, too, was at that farm. It was as he said ...

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Not with enough certainty to outweigh British interests in this fort.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: And who empowered these provincials to pass judgment upon England's policies in her own colonies? To come and go without so much as a "by your leave."

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: They do not live their lives "by your leave." ... They hack it out of the wilderness with their own two hands, burying their dead and their children along the way.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: You are defending him because you've become infatuated with him.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Duncan, you are a man with a few admirable qualities. But taken as a whole, I was wrong to have thought so highly of you.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: But the man is guilty of sedition and subject to military justice and beyond pardon.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: "Justice"? If that's "justice" ..., then the sooner French guns blow the English army out of America, the better it will be for these people.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: You do not know what you are saying!

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Yes I do! I know exactly what I am saying. And if it is sedition, then I am guilty of sedition, too!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Sorry ... can't ask you in.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: They're going to hang you.  Why didn't you leave when you had the chance?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Because what I am interested in is right here ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: What would you have me do?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Webb's reinforcements will arrive or not. If they do not arrive, the fort will fall. If that happens, stay close to your father. The French will protect the officer class among the English.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: No. I will find you.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Do not.  Promise me.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: The whole world's on fire, isn't it?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: This part of it sure is ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: I don't know. Whatever happens you stay with your father. You stay among the officers.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Colonel Munro, I have known you as a gallant antagonist. I am happy to make your acquaintance as a friend.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: And I to make yours, Monsieur le Marquis.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Please accept my compliments for the strong and skillful defense of your fortress. Under the command of a lesser man it would have fallen long ago given the superior numbers and material ... mere chance has allowed me to array against you ...

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Monsieur le Marquis, I am a soldier, not a diplomat. You called this parlay for a reason.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: You have already done everything which is necessary for the honor of your Prince. I will forever bear testimony that your resistance has been gallant and was continued as long as there was hope. But now, I beg you to listen to the admonitions of humanity. I beg you to consider my terms for your surrender.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: However I may apprise such testimony from Monsieur Montcalm, Fort William Henry is strong and stands.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Honor that is freely accorded to courage, may be refused obstinacy ... These hills afford to us every opportunity to reconnoiter your works and I am possibly as well acquainted with your weak condition as you are yourselves.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Perhaps the General's glasses can reach to the Hudson and he knows the size and imminence of the army of Webb ...?

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: My scouts intercepted this dispatch intended for you.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Read the dispatch.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: And I know the temper of our men. Rather than spend the war in a French prison hulk in Hudson Bay, they'd fight to the end.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Sir.  I am incapable of mistreating brave men. I beg you not to sign the death warrant of so many until you have listened to my terms.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Such as ...?

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: My master requires the fort be destroyed. But, for you and your comrades, there is no privilege that will be denied. None of your men will see the inside of a prison barge. They're free to go so long as they return to England and fight no more on this continent, and the civilian militia return to their farms.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Their arms?

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: They may leave the fortress fully armed, but with no ammunition ... Other than that, ask what you wish.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: The honors of war?

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Granted.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: My colors?

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Carry them to England to your King with pride.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Allow me to consult with my officers.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: I have lived to see two things I never expected. An Englishman afraid to support a friend. And a Frenchman too honest to profit by that advantage.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: General Webb can burn in hell. We'll go back and dig our graves behind the ramparts! Our mission is to fight.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Death and honor are sometimes thought to be the same. Today I have learned that they are not.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Sir!

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: The decision is final.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: I am deeply touched by such unusual and unexpected generosity ... The fort is yours under the condition that we be given until dawn to bury our dead, prepare our men and women for their march and turn our wounded over to your surgeon.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Granted, Monsieur.

Speaker: sentry
Dialogue: Qui vive?

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: France.

Speaker: sentry
Dialogue: Le mot d'ordre?

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: La victoire.

Speaker: sentry
Dialogue: C'est bien, vous vous promenez bien matin, monsieur!

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Il est necessaire d'etre vigilant, mon enfant.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Is the hatchet buried between the English and my French father?

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Not a warrior has a scalp and the white men become friends.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: My master owns these lands and your father has been ordered to drive off the English squatters. They have consented to go. So now he calls them enemies no longer.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Magua took the hatchet to color it with blood. It is still bright. Only when it is red, then it will be buried.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: But so many suns have set since Le Renard struck the war post. Is he not tired?

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Where is that sun?! It has gone behind the hill. It is dark and cold. It has set on his people, they are fooled and kill all the animals and sell all of their lands to enrich the European masters who are always greedy for more than they need.  And Le Subtil is the son of his tribe. There have been many clouds and many mountains. But now he has come to lead his nation.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: That Le Renard has the power to lead his people into the light, I know well.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Does my father know that?

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: That's where a lead bullet has torn you.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: And this?

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: My son has been sadly injured. Who did this?

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: In time Magua became blood-brother to Mohawk to become free. In his heart he always was Huron. And his heart will be whole again on the day when the Grey Hair and all his seed are dead!

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: My son Magua's pain is my pain.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Does the chief of the Canadas believe the English will keep the terms?

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: Munro would. But General Webb will not send their soldiers across the salt lake. Having let them go, I fear I will only fight the same men again when I move south.  And yet, I cannot break the terms of the capitulation and sully the lilies of France ...

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Many things my French father cannot do, Magua can.

Speaker: montcalm
Dialogue: As the English march away, our soldiers and the Canadiens will be drawn to the looting of the fort ... except for a small guard ...

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: I wonder at the blindness and pride of the white man. He believes only he knows how to speak falsely to make other men do his bidding.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Monsieur, the fort is yours.

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Steady! No one fires!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Men are to stay in file, Sergeant Major!

Speaker: sergeant major
Dialogue: Yes sir!

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Do not break ranks! I want these ranks to hold ...!

Speaker: sergeant major
Dialogue: Right - about face! March! First rank present!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Fire!

Speaker: sergeant major
Dialogue: Prime! Load! Second rank six paces forward! Present!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Fire!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Cora!

Speaker: munro
Dialogue: Cora! Alice!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Second rank fire! Six paces back! Prime! Load! Third rank! Present!

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Grey Hair. I will cut your heart from your living chest in front of your eyes. As you die, know that I will put under the knife your children and wipe your seed from this earth forever ...

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Six paces back! Prime! Load! Rank two, present! Rank two, hold!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Rank two, six paces back! Rank one, present!

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: You got nothin' better to do today on Lake George than shoot me, Major, then go ahead ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Stop it!!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: When you fall into British hands again, Nathaniel Poe, I will have you hanged.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Pull!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: How long?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: ... to get more distance on 'em and go to ground!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Pull!!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Pull ...!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Head for ... for the white water.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Do you hear me, sir!  What white water?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Here's where it gets tricky ...

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Don't move ...

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Where do we go from here?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: We don't.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: I don't understand!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: This is it, as far as we can go ... If we're lucky, they'll be figurin' we can't have come this way and must've beached our canoes and headed cross land. If we're very lucky, they'll figure we went over the falls.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Then what?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Then we take the south rim down the mountain and it's 12 miles cross country to Fort Edward.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: And if we're unlucky?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: You will have to forego the pleasure of hangin' me.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Any powder?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Are we safe?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Maybe ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Our father? Did you see my father?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Tell me!

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Say nothing to Alice ...!

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Uncas ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Yes. Go ahead.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: What the bloody hell plan is this?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: In this there is a chance. If I live, I can try to free you. If we don't go, there is no powder, there's too many of them. Though my heart would keep me here, in that there is no chance. None. I can do nothing. Do you understand?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Yes. I want you to go.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Coward! Coward back at the fort. Coward here.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: You try. With all you have. To save yourself. If the worst happens, and only one of us survives, something of the other does, too ...

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: If they don't kill you, they may take you north up into Canada. A warrior may take you for a wife.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Listen. Submit. You hear me? You're strong. You stay alive. I will find you ... no matter how far, how long it takes ...

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: ... never doubt what you are doing.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: If Magua give women to Yengeese soldiers ... will receive many gifts.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Gifts?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Three, four oxen ... much wampum.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Wampum?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Does Yengeese Major have property across salt sea?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Yengeese Major give all property to Magua. Magua give Yengeese Major much wampum, many gifts, maybe three, four oxen.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Gold could be arranged.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: For Munro children?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: How much gold has the master of the Yengeese?

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: The King? The King has mountains of gold!

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Not enough.

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: What is enough?

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Heart. Give Magua new heart.

Speaker: sachem
Dialogue: The tomahawks of your young men have been very red.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: I have brought three of my prisoners, to honor you. Two are the children of Munro. Whose scalp hangs on my lodge pole. And whose heart I cut from his chest.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: ... the earth was pale. Our tomahawks were bright. Now they are dull from war. And the Huron rich with the trophies of honor ... Magua will sell the English officer to Les Francais and the reward is my gift to you, wise one ... The women - children of the white war chief - will burn in our fires so all can share in this.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Nathaniel!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: I come to you unarmed and in peace to unstop your ears, wise one. Because the Hurons are mislead by the words of the wolf who's never spoken the truth.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Let the children of the dead Colonel Munro go free and take the fire out of the English anger over the murder of their helpless ones.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: Our father, Montcalm, is greater than the Yengeese in the arts of war. The Huron do not fear English anger.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Wise one, the French fathers made peace and swore to their honor not to break the friendship. Magua broke it. It is false that the French would not be friends, still, to the Huron.

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: It made our French father happy to never have to fight the same Yengeese again. He told me this without telling me this.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: So the Huron are the servants of the French? To do what the French are shamed to do?

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: No.  Huron serve no one. The French father believes he fooled Magua because he is so proud of his cleverness, he is blind. But it is the Huron path that Magua walks down, not the French one ... Now, Les Francais, also, fear Huron. That is good. When the Huron is strong from their fear, we will make the terms of trade with Les Francais. And we will trade as the white man trades. Take land from the Abnakes; fur from the Osage, Sauk & Fox. And make the Huron great. Over other tribes. No less than the whites, as strong as the whites.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Magua would use the ways of Les Francais and the Yengeese ...

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: The red man put down the bow, picked up the fire stick and became the best warrior in the forest. Yes. It is the only way.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Would the Huron make his Algonquin brothers foolish with brandy and steal his lands to sell them for gold to the white man? Would the Huron have greed for more land than a man can use? Like Francais Black Robes do? Would Huron kill tribes with disease? Would the Huron fool Seneca into taking all the animals in the forest for beads & brandy? But sell the fur to the white man for gold? ...  I am Nathaniel of the Yengeese; Hawkeye, adopted son of Chingachgook, of the Mohican people ... Let the children of the dead Munro go free ... I speak the truth.

Speaker: sachem
Dialogue: The white man comes like a day that has passed. And night enters our future with him ...  Dark girl burn in fire to heal the twisted heart of Magua.

Speaker: sachem
Dialogue: Munro daughter with moon in her hair must be Magua's wife so Munro's seed doesn't die.

Speaker: sachem
Dialogue: ... and Yengeese officer not go to Les Francais, but back to Yengeese so their hatred burns less bright. La Longue Carabine, go in peace.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: No! listen.  Tell him I'll trade him! Me for her! Tell him!!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: I am La Longue Carabine! My death is a great honor to the Huron. Take me!

Speaker: magua
Dialogue: This is not the voice of wisdom. I go to the Hurons of the Lakes! You are women. Send your arrows and guns to the Seneca, beg from them venison to eat, corn to grind. Slaves, dogs, rabbits, thieves ... I spit on you!

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: I said to trade me!

Speaker: heyward
Dialogue: ... compliments, Mr. Poe.  Take her and get out.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: What are they doing to Duncan? Duncan!

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Alice?

Speaker: chingachgook
Dialogue: UNCAS!!!

Speaker: chingachgook
Dialogue: Great Spirit and the Maker of all Life ...

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Will you go back to England?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: I have nothing to go back for.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Then will you stay in America?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: And will you be my wife?

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: cora
Dialogue: Where will we go?

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: Winter with the Delaware, my father's cousins. And in the spring, cross the Ohio and look for land to settle with my father in a new place called Can-tuck-ee.

Speaker: chingachgook
Dialogue: The frontier moves with the sun and pushes the red man of the wilderness forests in front of it. Until one day there will be nowhere left. Then our race will be no more, or be not us ... The frontier place is for people like my white son and his woman and their children.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: That's my father's sadness talking.

Speaker: chingachgook
Dialogue: No. It is true ... One day ... there will be no more frontier. Then men like you will go, too. Like the Mohicans.  And new people will come. Work. Struggle to make their light ... One mystery remains.

Speaker: hawkeye
Dialogue: What is that?

Speaker: chingachgook
Dialogue: Will there be anything left to show the world that we ever did exist?
